chapter.title: sudo
chapter.para:
Many commands and system utilities need to be run as &rootuser; to modify files and/or perform tasks that only the super user is allowed to.
For security purposes and to avoid running dangerous commands accidentially, it is generally disregarded to log in as &rootuser; directly. Instead, it is recommended to work as a normal, unprivileged, user and use the &sudo; command to run commands with elevated privileges.

In its default configuration, &sudo; is, apart of different options, similiar to su. Compared to su, &sudo; offers the possibility to allow users to run commands with privileges of any other user in a highly configurable manner. While su always uses PAM for authenticating as target user, &sudo; makes it possible to authenticate with your own credentials. This increases security by not having to share the &rootuser; password.
For instance, you can allow members of the group &examplegroup; to run a command frobnicate as &exampleuserII;, with the restriction that no arguments are specified. This can be used to assign roles with specific abilities to certain users and groups.

sect1.title: Basic &sudo; usage
sect1.para: &sudo; is simple to use, yet very powerful.

sect2.title: Running a single command
sect2.para: Logged in as normal user, you can run any command as &rootuser; by prepending it with &sudo;. It will prompt for the root password and, if authenticated sucessfully, run the command as &rootuser;:
sect2.screen:
&prompt.user;id -un tux &prompt.user;sudo id -un root's password: root &prompt.user;id -un tux &prompt.user;sudo id -un
root

callout.para: The id command prints information about a user, the current one if not specified.
The password is not shown during input, neither as clear text nor as bullets.
Only the single command is run with elevated privileges, those after &sudo; are run as normal user again.
For a limited amount of time you do not need to enter the &rootuser; password again.

tip.title: I/O redirection
tip.para: I/O redirection does not directly work that way:
tip.screen: &prompt.user; sudo echo s > /proc/sysrq-trigger bash: /proc/sysrq-trigger: Permission denied &prompt.user; sudo cat < /proc/1/maps bash: /proc/1/maps: Permission denied
tip.para:
Only the echo/cat binary is run with elevated privileges, while the redirection is performed by the user's shell.
You can either start a shell like in or use the dd utility instead:
tip.screen: echo s | sudo dd of=/proc/sysrq-trigger sudo dd if=/proc/1/maps | cat

sect2.title: Starting a shell
sect2.para: Having to prepend &sudo; to every command can be cumbersome. While you can specify a shell as a command: sudo bash, there are two options specifically for this purpose.

listitem.para: Starts a shell specified by the SHELL environment variable or the target user's settings. If a command is given, it is passed to the shell (with the -c option), else the shell is run in interactive mode.
Like -s, but start the shell as login shell. This means that the shell's start-up files (.profile etc.) are read and the current working directory is set to the target user's HOME.

sect2.title: Environment variables
sect2.para: By default, &sudo; does not propagate environment variables:
sect2.screen:
&prompt.user;ENVVAR=test env | grep ENVVAR ENVVAR=test &prompt.user;ENVVAR=test sudo env | grep ENVVAR root's password:
&prompt.user;

callout.para: The empty output shows that the environment variable ENVVAR did not exist in the context of the command run with &sudo;.

sect2.para: This behavior can be changed by the env_reset option, see .

sect1.title: Configuring &sudo;
sect1.para: &sudo; is a very flexible tool with extensive configuration.

note.title: Locked out of sudo
note.para: Should you lock yourself out of &sudo; by mistake, you can use su - and the &rootuser; password to get a root shell.

sect2.title: Editing the configuration files
sect2.para: The main policy configuration file for &sudo; is /etc/sudoers. As it is possible to lock yourself out of the system if there are any errors in that file, it is strongly recommended to use visudo for editing. It will prevent simultaneous changes to the opened file and check for syntax errors before saving.
Despite its name, you can also use editors other than vi by setting the EDITOR environment variable, for example:

However, the /etc/sudoers file itself is supplied by the system packages and modifications may break on updates. Therefore, it is recommended to put any custom configuration into the /etc/sudoers.d/ directory. Any file in there is automatically included. To edit a file in that subdirectory, run:

note.title: Ignored files in /etc/sudoers.d
note.para: The #includedir command in /etc/sudoers, used for /etc/sudoers.d, ignores files that end in ~ or contain a ..

sect2.para: For more info on the visudo command, run man 8 visudo.

sect2.title: Basic sudoers syntax
sect2.para: The most important syntax constructs for /etc/sudoers and files under /etc/sudoers.d are:
sect2.screen: # Everything on a line after a # gets ignored Defaults !insults # Disable the insults flag Defaults env_keep += "DISPLAY HOME" # Add DISPLAY and HOME to env_keep &exampleuser_plain; ALL = NOPASSWD: /usr/bin/frobnicate, PASSWD: /usr/bin/journalctl

callout.para: There are two exceptions: #include and #includedir are normal commands. Followed by digits, it specifies a UID.
Remove the ! to enable the flag.

entry.para: This flag controls whether the invoking user is required to enter the password of the target user (&rootuser;) (ON), or his own password (OFF). The default is ON.

entry.screen: Defaults targetpw # Turn targetpw flag ON

entry.para: If set, &sudo; will prompt for the &rootuser; password instead of the target user's or the invoker's. The default is OFF.

If set, &sudo; constructs a minimal environment with only TERM, PATH, HOME, MAIL, SHELL, LOGNAME, USER, USERNAME and SUDO_* set. Additionally, variables listed in env_keep get imported from the calling environment. The default is ON.

entry.screen: Defaults env_reset # Turn env_reset flag ON

entry.para: List of environment variables to keep when the env_reset flag is ON.

entry.screen: # Set env_keep to contain EDITOR and PROMPT Defaults env_keep = "EDITOR PROMPT" Defaults env_keep += "JRE_HOME" # Add JRE_HOME Defaults env_keep -= "JRE_HOME" # Remove JRE_HOME

entry.para: List of environment variables to remove when the env_reset flag is OFF.

entry.screen: # Set env_delete to contain EDITOR and PROMPT Defaults env_delete = "EDITOR PROMPT" Defaults env_delete += "JRE_HOME" # Add JRE_HOME Defaults env_delete -= "JRE_HOME" # Remove JRE_HOME

sect2.para: The Defaults token can also be used to create aliases for a collection of users, hosts and commands. Furthermore, it is possible to apply an option setting only to a specific set of users.
For detailed information about the /etc/sudoers configuration file, consult man 5 sudoers.

sect2.title: Rules in sudoers
sect2.para: Rules in sudoers can be very complex, so this section will only touch the basics. Each rule follows the basic scheme ([] marks optional parts):
sect2.screen: #Who Where As whom Tag What User_List Host_List = [(User_List)] [NOPASSWD:|PASSWD:] Cmnd_List

listitem.para: One or more (separated by ,) identifiers: Either a user name, a group in the format %GROUPNAME or a user ID in the format #UID. Each identifier can be prefixed by ! for negation.
One or more (separated by ,) identifiers: Either a (fully qualified) host name or an IP address. Each identifier can be prefixed by ! for negation. ALL is the usual choice for this.
The user will not be prompted for a password when running commands matching CMDSPEC after NOPASSWD:.
PASSWD is the default, it only needs to be specified when both are on the same line:
One or more (separated by ,) specifiers: A path to an executable, followed by allowed arguments or nothing.
listitem.screen: /usr/bin/foo # Anything allowed /usr/bin/foo bar # Only "/usr/bin/foo bar" allowed /usr/bin/foo "" # No arguments allowed

sect2.para: ALL can be used as User_List, Host_List and Cmnd_List.

sect1.title: Common use cases
sect1.para: Although the default configuration is often sufficient for simple setups and desktops, custom configurations can be very useful.

sect2.title: Using &sudo; without &rootuser; password
sect2.para: In cases with special restrictions (user X can only run command Y as &rootuser;) it is not possible. In other cases, it is still favorable to have some kind of separation. By convention, members of the group wheel can run all commands with &sudo; as root.

step.title: Add yourself to the wheel group
step.para: If your user account is not already member of the wheel group, add it by running sudo usermod -a -G wheel USERNAME and logging out and -in again. Verify that the change was successful by running groups USERNAME.

step.title: Make authentication with the invoking user's password the default.

step.title: Select a new default rule
step.para: Depending on whether you want users to re-enter their passwords, uncomment the specific line in /etc/sudoers and comment out the default rule.
step.screen:
## Uncomment to allow members of group wheel to execute any command # %wheel ALL=(ALL) ALL
## Same thing without a password # %wheel ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL

step.title: Make the default rule more restrictive
step.para: Comment out or remove the allow-everything rule in /etc/sudoers:
step.screen: ALL ALL=(ALL) ALL # WARNING! Only use this together with 'Defaults targetpw'!

warning.title: Dangerous rule in sudoers
warning.para: Do not forget this step, otherwise any user can execute any command as &rootuser;!

step.title: Test the configuration
step.para: Try to run &sudo; as member and not-member of wheel.
step.screen: &exampleuser_plain;:~ > groups users wheel &exampleuser_plain;:~ > sudo id -un &exampleuser_plain;'s password: root &exampleuserII_plain;:~ > groups users &exampleuserII_plain;:~ > sudo id -un &exampleuserII_plain; is not in the sudoers file. This incident will be reported.

sect2.title: Using &sudo; with &xvendor; applications
sect2.para: When starting graphical applications with &sudo;, you will encounter the following error:
sect2.screen: &prompt.user;sudo xterm xterm: Xt error: Can't open display: %s xterm: DISPLAY is not set
sect2.para: &yast; will pick the ncurses interface instead of the graphical one.

To use &xvendor; in applications started with &sudo;, the environment variables DISPLAY and XAUTHORITY need to be propagated. To configure this, create the file /etc/sudoers.d/xorg, (see ) and add the following line:
If not set already, set the XAUTHORITY variable as follows: export XAUTHORITY=~/.Xauthority Now &xvendor; applications can be run as usual:

sect1.title: More Information
sect1.para: A quick overview about the available command line switches can be retrieved by sudo --help. An explanation and other important information can be found in the man page: man 8 sudo, while the configuration is documented on man 5 sudoers.
